Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Compressed Network Tomography and Data Collection in Large-Scale Wireless Sensor Networking

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Our physical world presents an incredibly rich set of observation modalities. Recent advances in wireless sensor networks (WSNs) enable the continuous monitoring of various physical phenomena at unprecedented high spatial densities and long time durations, hence opening exciting new opportunities for numerous scientific endeavors. Since sensor nodes are unattended and batterypowered, network monitoring/tomography from indirect measurements at the sink(s) and energy conservation are critical in the deployment of large-scale environmental WSNs. Therefore, a viable framework for energy-efficient network monitoring and data collection is fundamentally important to significantly improve WSN management/operations and reduce its deployment costs.

This project investigates the energy-efficient network monitoring/tomography and data collections in large-scale outdoor WSNs, based on the recent breakthrough of compressed sensing (CS) through an integrated theoretical and empirical approach. The project studies WSN topology tomography for dynamic routing under wireless link dynamics due to channel fading and interference. The objectives of this project are to develop a novel and rigorous framework of topology tomography for real-world WSNs operated in highly noisy communication environments. Dynamic routing topology recovery algorithms are devised for both complete indirect measurements and incomplete indirect measurements received at the sink(s). The accuracy of the tomography approach is studied both analytically and empirically. The developed WSN topology tomography framework can be essential not only for WSN's routing improvement, topology control, hot spot elimination, and anomaly detection in practice, but also for emerging CS-based data collection. This approach extends the current CS technology to form a unified framework for network tomography and data collection in large-scale WSNs, upon which energy-efficient WSN topology tomography and data gathering protocol suite is developed. The developed framework and protocol suite will be validated and evaluated in a real-world environmental WSN testbed in a hilly watershed.

The project intends to create a new paradigm of optimal design, development, and management/operations for large-scale WSNs to significantly extend their lifetime. This would lead to a substantial reduction of the prohibitive cost of large-scale WSN deployments for scientific, civic, national security, and military purposes in the near future. The project creates an interdisciplinary educational practice for both undergraduate and graduate students through hands-on experience with a real-world WSN testbed. The outreach includes summer camps and scientific projects for school students using the WSN testbed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The sustainable conditions of freshwater resources partially depend on our understanding of the natural system in which they are cycled. Hydrological processes play a fundamental role in the soil–atmosphere interactions and eco-hydrological processes. Moreover, their impacts on regional hydrologic and climatologic conditions need long-term in situ measurements for verification and validation.

Ground-based measurements and monitoring of environmental variables have been drastically improved over the past decade by wireless sensor network (WSN) technology. Wireless monitoring devices provide scalable-high-resolution data at an ever reducing cost and have been adopted in a wide variety of fields of environmental monitoring (e.g., habitat monitoring, microclimate monitoring, seismology, understory sunlight studies, agriculture, ecology and hydrology). High-resolution sensor networks for hydrology is one of the growing applications of WSNs due, in part, to the increasing needs for understanding spatio-termporal variability of hydrological processes at small scales and for characterizing sub-grid spatial variability of hydrological variables from airborne and space-borne measurements.

Via this project, a long-term (over eight years) WSN has been deployed in a forested environment at the Audubon Society of Western Pennsylvania (ASWP) to measure edaphic (e.g., moisture, water potential and temperature) and arboreal (i.e., xylem sap flow) hydrological properties. One of the original motivations of this project was to determine the feasibility of continuous and reliable collection of hydrological data under natural field conditions. Following the successful deployment of the network, a new initiative was started in 2015 to further expand the network and improve the data collection and processing efforts.

The novelty of this study includes: 1) a data acquisition board design and software driver for integrating digital environmental sensors into the wireless hardware platform; 2) an energy efficient and balanced routing protocol; and 3) a heterogeneous over-the-air mote reprogramming tool. This study focuses on the following: 1) data quality assessment from soil moisture (SM), soil water potential (WP) and soil temperature (ST) sensors attached to the WSN nodes using a specially designed sensor board; 2) high quality sap flow (SF) measurements from lab-made Granier-style sensors; 3) the application of the collected data to: a) estimate soil hydraulic properties, b) calculate transpiration based on SF, c) explore spatiotemporal patterns of SM and WP; and 4) evaluation of the utility of WSNs for environmental monitoring applications. 

The 104-node outdoor WSN collects environmental data from over 240 sensors, including the EC-5, MPS-1 and MPS-2 (Decagon Devices) SM and WP sensors and, self-made SF sensors, across a heterogeneous deployment comprised of MICAz, IRIS (MEMSIC) and TelosB wireless motes. Innovative techniques (e.g., balanced energy efficient routing and heterogeneous over-the-air mote reprogramming) effectively maintained high success rates (> 96%) throughout the multi-hop wireless sensor network. The soil properties monitored by the network showed strong agreement with data logger measurements and were fitted to pedotransfer functions (PTF) for estimating local soil hydraulic properties. Furthermore, SF measurements, scaled to tree stand transpiration, were found to be consistent with the estimated potential evapotranspiration patterns and within suggested range estimates. In terms of data quality and quantity and long-term reliable collections,  outdoor WSNs still need to overcome numerous challenges.   By incorporating the innovations of the study, our  ASWP testbed proves that WSN can be an effective and low-cost environmental monitoring solution.

This study has also presented a comprehensive data analysis for the aforementioned WSN-monitored- hydrological variables. Two PTF parameters (utilized by hydrologic models to predict soil water retention properties) - the Clapp-Hornberger and the van Genuchten equations, were estimated based on SM and WP data. A good match between observed and modelled data was achieved, based on the Nash-Sutcliffe efficiency (NSE) criterion (>0.80). The improved installation design of the SF sensors allowed to retrieve high-quality data, that was used to estimate transpiration rates. These estimations were consistent with previous studies at sites with similar geographic and climatic characteristics as the ones at the ASWP site and, with the local measured data (meteorological stations). Moreover, a spatial analysis showed the variability of SM and WP, and the applicability of WSN for short- and long-term hydrological pattern characterizations of a forested environment at a catchment scale.

Finally, the presented WSN approach (e.g., network protocols, sensors, deployment tool, and data acquisition) has proved to be an effective (in terms of the data quantity and quality) and low-cost alternative for environmental monitoring despite of the tremendous challenges posed by outdoor WSN deployments, including power management, node maintenance, routing scale, and heterogeneous deployment. One important contribution of the study is that our results may pave the way to have larger scale outdoor WSN deployments in the future to investigate impacts of soil and vegetation sub-grid heterogeneity on hydrologic processes and to explore fundamental science questions.
